title: What camp is Daniel Dennett in on the problem of consciousness? - Quora

response.answer_text: I. Dennett’s objection to the hard problem Dennett thinks the “hard problem of consciousness” is akin to a hypothetical “hard problem of symphonies” – a philosophical problem I’m inventing here for the sake of analogy. The easy problems of symphonies would be questions like: how does an instrument make a sound, how do individual notes convey a chord, and why can melody coexist with harmony? The hard problem though, is why do symphonies exist? Just what are symphonies, exactly? When you posit a hard problem, you imply an explanation, or at least a mystery: Isn’t a symphony, taken as a whole—with tempo, with its mood, its performance, its sense of narrative—isn’t that something special? Isn’t it more than the sum of the answers to the easy questions? Isn’t “symphonyness” a fundamental, irreducible element of the universe? In Dennett’s view, no. Not breaking the question down into its component parts is basically mysticism. It’s a philosophical mistake. [Here’s brief Dennett article using life and cuteness as fundamental properties the universe as analogies: http://ase.tufts.edu/cogstud/dennett/papers/chalmers.htm] I have tried to show that however compelling the intuition may be that we must not break up the conscious Subject into lots of parts that are not, themselves, conscious, this intuition must be abandoned. The tempting idea that there is a Hard Problem is simply a mistake. I cannot prove this. — https://ase.tufts.edu/cogstud/dennett/papers/explainingmagic.pdf (emphasis mine)  II. Dennett’s model Dennett’s explains the popularity of the hard problem as the excessive influence of Descartes’s ideas. Per Descartes, people envision a tiny “observer-me” inside their mind, watching the show put on by their sensory organs. In Consciousness Explained, he calls this imaginary stage-and-audience the Cartesian theater. Dennett says that instead of this single “executive” in the brain, watching the show, consciousness is well enough explained by multiple simultaneous functions: The basic idea is that consciousness is more like fame than television; it is not a special “medium of representation” in the brain into which content-bearing events must be transduced in order to become conscious. — https://ase.tufts.edu/cogstud/dennett/papers/cognition.fin.htm(emphasis mine) • • • According to Dennett, consciousness is to be found in the actions and flows of information from place to place, rather than some singular view containing our experience. — Multiple drafts model  III. The consequence and scope of Dennett’s model Dennett still believes that subjective experience is confusing, limited, sometimes contradictory, and frequently hard to describe. Accepting those statements doesn’t necessitate belief in a hard problem of consciousness. The hard problem presumes that the sum of the parts isn’t enough to account for consciousness. Dennett says the sum of the parts seems good enough. At the very least, he sees a mysterious essence of consciousness as something neuroscience shouldn’t bother to look for. To be fair, Dennett oscillates between a) sneering at questions about consciousness as unremarkable and trivially explained by known cognitive functions [especially when the questions come from Chalmers] and b) acknowledging that the illusion of consciousness as “special stuff” is compelling. He [hard problem advocate David Chalmers] can appeal to your intuitions, but this is not a sound basis on which to found a science of consciousness. We have seen in the past and I have given a few simple examples here that we have a powerful tendency to inflate our inventory of known effects of consciousness, so we must be alert to the possibility that we are being victimized by an error of arithmetic, in effect, when we take ourselves to have added up all the Easy Problems and discovered a residue unaccounted for. — https://ase.tufts.edu/cogstud/dennett/papers/explainingmagic.pdf  IV. Outside Dennett Think of Dennett’s argument as showing us why the assumptions of the hard problem aren’t proven. That’s different than disproving the assumptions of the hard problem. The next question then is this: Are there any consequences or interesting implications in Dennett’s acknowledgment that we can’t prove the hard problem is a mistake? Interesting is subjective, but for me, I think so. I’ll offer two of many examples: A. Consider the way that many physicalists of the Dennett persuasion (though not Dennett himself, at least not always) are eager to downgrade the mystery of human consciousness by, for example, labeling autonomous cars as sentient or conscious. What if a hacker installs a virus that causes the car to tell you it’s terrified of parking in your driveway? In what sense is the car terrified? Have you wronged your sentient car by parking it in your driveway? Or is it a “philosophical zombie”? What happens when you—as Dennett acknowledges you might—begin to struggle to tell the difference? Can science or philosophy do anything to address this? B. Imagine in the future that technological groups want to make robot intelligence mimic human consciousness more closely. If Dennett’s theory of consciousness is right, is that even ethical? Wouldn’t we be, in effect, programming a sentient being into potentially painful cognitive shackles? How would we program human-like distractibility? Our ability to hold conflicting beliefs at one time? How would we even emulate the experience of peripheral vision? If these hypotheticals read like a criticism of Dennett, you aren’t getting it. These hypotheticals accept Dennett, and then ask what the implications are. The point is that you don’t have to believe consciousness is magic to find aspects of it mysterious, hard to draw a line around, and worth pondering. I believe that Dennett would agree.  A caveat: In defense of hard-problem doubters, I should acknowledge that believers overstep at least as frequently. Believers in the hard problem, in the specialness of consciousness, claim their side proven too. Dennett acknowledges that neither view can be proven in philosophical sense. It would be nice if the conversation could start from there more often.
